label: BODY

text: Published by Canadian Center of Science and Education
label: BODY

text: EFL Teachers’ Background Knowledge is the Key to Learners’ Needs
label: TITLE

text: Salwa Al Darwish1
label: BODY

text: 1 Public Authority for Applied Education & Training, College of Basic Education, Kuwait
label: BODY

text: Correspondence: Salwa Al Darwish, Public Authority for Applied Education & Training, College of Basic
label: BODY

text: Education, Al Shamiya, Block 9, Street 93, Kuwait. Tel: 965-9901-3946. E-mail: salwaaldarwish@hotmail.com
label: BODY

text: Received: August 27, 2012   Accepted: October 30, 2012   Online Published: November 14, 2012
label: BODY

text: doi:10.5539/ies.v5n6p251               URL: http://dx.doi.org/10.5539/ies.v5n6p251
label: BODY

text: Abstract
label: HH1

text: This study aimed at examining an unorthodox approach in which teacher trainees observe experienced teachers
label: BODY

text: to benefit from their professional experience instead of the more common practice in which teacher trainees are
label: BODY

text: evaluated through self-reflection and peer review. The target population was 111 teachers randomly selected by
label: BODY

text: 20 teacher trainees teaching English in 20 schools within 6 school districts in Kuwait. A mixed method of
label: BODY

text: questionnaire and observation by the teacher trainees was used for data collection. The results showed a
label: BODY

text: discrepancy between the questionnaire responses and personal observation. The questionnaire responses
label: BODY

text: indicated that the teachers had significant confidence, high competency, and excellent performance. However,
label: BODY

text: classroom observation revealed that EFL teachers had to plan their classes with constraints of limited teaching
label: BODY

text: hours and resources and mixed levels of proficiency and learning environment. Thus, Kuwaiti EFL teachers have
label: BODY

text: the ability, proficiency, and confidence to teach EFL, but lack the required freedom from the educational
label: BODY

text: authorities to implement their methods.
label: BODY

text: Keywords: EFL teachers, instruction technique, teacher trainees, questionnaire, Kuwait
label: HH1

text: 1. Introduction
label: HH1

text: 1.1 Study Background
label: BODY

text: Traditionally, language teaching has been described in terms of what teachers do: that is, in terms of the actions
label: BODY

text: and behaviors of teachers in the classroom and the effects of these on learners (Rea & Mercuri, 2006). Richards
label: BODY

text: and Lockhart (2007) as well as Nunan (1999, 2005) mentioned that regardless of the class a teacher teaches, he or
label: BODY

text: she is typically confronted with different kinds of tasks. For example, these tasks include observing students’
label: BODY

text: interactions, developing materials for the topic of the day, discussing reading materials, brainstorming for certain
label: BODY

text: topics to write, problem solving, creating certain games to stimulate and assist students’ understandings, etc. In
label: BODY

text: trying to understand how teachers deal with these tasks of teaching, it is necessary to examine the beliefs and
label: BODY

text: thinking processes that underlie teachers’ classroom actions through giving her/his lessons (Krashen, 1998). Even
label: BODY

text: though self-observation of the teachers would be the first step in consciously understanding one’s weaknesses, and
label: BODY

text: followed by an action plan to address those weaknesses (Richards & Renandaya, 2008), with this study self
label: BODY

text: observation was not carried out by teacher trainees to observe and evaluate themselves because many teachers
label: BODY

text: never reflect on why they teach as they do. On the one hand, Richards also added that self-observation gives the
label: BODY

text: younger teachers who are in the first stage of their careers a far greater insight into their own teaching habits by
label: BODY

text: emphasizing the effective ways of improving and understanding their own teaching; on the other hand, self
label: BODY

text: observation is an unfamiliar process that might create conflict in their personal and teaching values. However, by
label: BODY

text: observing experienced teachers, teacher trainees know their current status with regard to teaching, and this helps
label: BODY

text: them decide what they need to do to reach their goals. In addition, Pachier and Field (2001) expressed their
label: BODY

text: concern that in order to be an effective foreign language teacher, the individual needs a commitment to keep up
label: BODY

text: with the recent developments in the field and a willingness to engage in continuous professional development.
label: BODY

text: Therefore, observing experienced teachers would have more effect on newly graduate teachers than by any other
label: BODY

text: means.
label: BODY

text: 1.2 Research Motivation
label: BODY

text: This study was motivated by the desire to provide useful information about the strategies of instructions carried
label: BODY

text: out by the English language teachers inside the classroom in general and the teaching of English as a Foreign
label: BODY

text: Language (EFL) in Kuwaiti elementary school context specifically. Kuwaiti English education can be
label: BODY

text: www.ccsenet.org/ies
label: BODY

text: International Education Studies
label: BODY

text: categorized as a true foreign language learning context rather than as an English as a Second Language (ESL)
label: BODY

text: situation. That is, outside the classroom, English is rarely used, and the classroom instruction is most likely the
label: BODY

text: only input for the target language learning. Although the learners have 12 years of foreign language education
label: BODY

text: starting from elementary stage till the end of high school, these learners receive limited target language input and
label: BODY

text: have limited language learning time. Because of the large gap between what students are learning with regard to
label: BODY

text: EFL and not ESL within the public schools in Kuwait, students show poor academic achievement at the
label: BODY

text: university level especially when the medium of instruction and all the text books are in English in certain
label: BODY

text: colleges such as the School of Engineer, Medical School, and the College of Art and Science (2011 English
label: BODY

text: Department Statistics, at CBE). So, this level of academic achievement stems not from lack of intelligence but
label: BODY

text: from the manner of exposure to the target language English. As a preliminary step toward improving Kuwaiti
label: BODY

text: English education, the present study aims at exploring and describing the actual scenario in the English
label: BODY

text: classrooms in Kuwait from the teacher trainees’ perspectives, because these young female teacher trainees are
label: BODY

text: prospective future teachers and are in the first stage of their careers. They will be more open to certain
label: BODY

text: professional critique, especially if this critique comes from experienced teachers who have been teaching for
label: BODY

text: many years in this field. Furthermore, teachers often work in isolation and do not always have opportunities to
label: BODY

text: benefit from the collective expertise of their colleagues. One way to avoid this is to build in opportunities for
label: BODY

text: collaborative planning, for example, when teachers work together in pairs or groups on course planning, material
label: BODY

text: development, and lesson planning. So, it is best to encourage teacher trainees to report their positive teaching
label: BODY

text: experiences by examining how experienced teachers conduct their lesson inside the classroom. In addition, these
label: BODY

text: teacher trainees are more ready to take risks by implementing new ideas gained from observation and practice, in
label: BODY

text: addition to those they learn theoretically. Therefore, as explained by Koksal (2011), letting these young teacher
label: BODY

text: trainees observe, learn, and gain guidance from experienced teachers would be more effective and acceptable
label: BODY

text: than guidance from any other individual as well as self observation.
label: BODY

text: 1.3 Research Objectives
label: BODY

text: This study attempts to answer the following questions:
label: BODY

text: What teaching techniques do teachers try to implement in their classroom?
label: BODY

text: To what extent is the teacher’s performance inside the classroom similar to her response in the
label: BODY

text: questionnaire?
label: BODY

text: What teaching resources do teachers make use of? and why?
label: BODY

text: With regard to the above research questions, it could be said that it is essential for the teacher trainees who are in
label: BODY

text: the first stage of their careers to show initial commitment and enthusiasm (Day, 1999). Koksal (2011), in his
label: BODY

text: article on English Language Teachers working in elementary schools in Turkey, explained that their main goal
label: BODY

text: was to improve the performance of teachers in Turkish schools, so they came up with training programs for
label: BODY

text: young teachers, and renewed and shared the knowledge of experienced teachers. Therefore, it would be more
label: BODY

text: effective if these teacher trainees attentively watch their colleagues or experienced teachers so that they can get
label: BODY

text: help and guidance and identify their areas of strength and weakness from these experienced teachers. If teachers
label: BODY

text: are expected to teach well and develop their teaching skills and knowledge over time, they need ongoing support.
label: BODY

text: This may take a number of forms. New teachers need a careful orientation to teaching assignments in order to
label: BODY

text: clarify the goals of the program, teaching approaches, resources, problems to anticipate, and their solutions. So,
label: BODY

text: when teacher trainees connect with experienced teachers for mentoring and support as needed during their
label: BODY

text: practicum period, they are encouraged to set higher goals and expend more personal effort, which in the end
label: BODY

text: improves their self-confidence.
label: BODY

text: 1.4 Literature Review
label: BODY

text: For a long time in foreign/second language education, language has been viewed as an ‘object’ which is to be
label: BODY

text: analyzed and broken down into its smallest components (Rea & Mercuri, 2006). According to Dornyei (2007),
label: BODY

text: the teacher does not consider the students empty vessels that need to be filled with words of wisdom coming
label: BODY

text: entirely from the teacher and the course book. Therefore, the teacher’s role has been to help students learn what
label: BODY

text: is in the textbook that is mostly grammar driven, and the study of foreign /second language teaching has been
label: BODY

text: largely decontextualized and unrelated to students’ real life (Tedick & Walker, 1995). On the one hand, Phillips
label: BODY

text: explained that both vocabulary and grammar need to be taught in context, and should be used by students in
label: BODY

text: class (2010). On the other hand, Reyes and Vallone (2008) added that gaining knowledge of what is not
label: BODY

text: dependent on the individual, but on social interaction and culturally situated contexts can motivate students to
label: BODY

text: use the target language and shape their communication competence. Morris (1995) observed that schools
label: BODY

text: develop a culture, ethos, or environment that might be favorable or unfavorable to change and innovations. A
label: BODY

text: www.ccsenet.org/ies
label: BODY

text: International Education Studies
label: BODY

text: school with a relatively open climate, where the teachers collaborate with each other and where the principal and
label: BODY

text: senior teachers are supportive of younger teachers, is more likely to try and implement change. In contrast, a
label: BODY

text: school where the principle focuses on administrative matters, the teachers work in isolation or in narrow
label: BODY

text: subject-based groups, and where there is no mechanism to discuss and try to solve problems is less likely to
label: BODY

text: change. For example, if a school encourages innovation and successful implementation of foreign language
label: BODY

text: teaching, the teachers might introduce material from English-speaking cultures. This in turn is interesting to the
label: BODY

text: students because the lives of children in foreign places give a more human face to the language they are learning.
label: BODY

text: Based on Al Dabbous and Howells experience (1994) with English teaching in Kuwait, EFL exams mainly
label: BODY

text: concern structure in the target language that students fear and intensely dislike. They observed that the only way
label: BODY

text: to acquire such knowledge is by extensive reading and listening. In language teaching history, the acquisition of
label: BODY

text: linguistic structures or vocabulary has been emphasized for a long time, and it has been acknowledged that
label: BODY

text: structures and vocabulary is important (Richards & Renandya, 2008). However, many researchers (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: Widdowson, 1995; Freeman, 1998) insisted that preparation for communication will be inadequate if only these
label: BODY

text: are taught. That is, they argued that students might know the rules of language usage, but would be unable to use
label: BODY

text: the language (Gebhard, 2005). Traditionally, language teaching has been explored in terms of what teachers do
label: BODY

text: in the classroom, that is, the manner in which they carry out these tasks (Littlewood, 1992). It is, however,
label: BODY

text: assumed that “what teachers do is a reflection of what they know and believe in, and that teacher knowledge and
label: BODY

text: ‘teacher thinking’ provide the underlying framework or schema which guides the teacher’s classroom actions”
label: BODY

text: (Richards & Lockhart, 2000). It is, therefore, required to examine the thinking processes which underlie
label: BODY

text: teachers’ classroom actions (Richards & Lockhart, 2007).
label: BODY

text: Through his investigation of 105 EFL teachers’ practices about their language teaching, Johnson (1982)
label: BODY

text: concluded that “teachers teach in accordance with their theoretical beliefs and that differences in theoretical
label: BODY

text: beliefs may result in differences in the nature of literacy instruction” (pp 101). Reyes and Vallone (2008) believe
label: BODY

text: that a teacher is effective only if her students have access to a curriculum that closely mirrors their culture.
label: BODY

text: Goldfus (2011) emphasized that foreign language teachers must direct the attention of the foreign language
label: BODY

text: educators toward the acquisition of the literacy within the structure and components of not only the learner's
label: BODY

text: native language but also the target language. Also, Richards and Lockhart (2007) argued that “any language
label: BODY

text: teaching program reflects both the culture of the institution as well as collective decisions and beliefs of
label: BODY

text: individual teachers.... Within a program or school, teachers’ views on such things as lesson planning, use of
label: BODY

text: objectives, and assessment may lead to quite different classroom practices” (pp 38). Thompson (1992) noticed
label: BODY

text: that “teachers interact with their environment, some experience no conflict between their beliefs and their
label: BODY

text: practice, and some learn to live with unresolved conflicts” (pp 138). However, Edge (cited in Bailey, Curtis, &
label: BODY

text: Nunan, 2001) states that working in isolation holds teachers back.
label: BODY

text: 2. Methodology
label: HH1

text: 2.1 Participants and the Settings
label: BODY

text: This study focused on 111 female Kuwaiti EFL teachers who currently teach English as a foreign language in 20
label: BODY

text: elementary public schools located in the 6 school districts in the State of Kuwait. These schools in Kuwait are
label: BODY

text: segregated into all-girl and all-boy schools. Only female teachers teach both genders in these schools because the
label: BODY

text: Ministry of Education (MOE) in the State of Kuwait stipulates this gender segregation. Like all Kuwaiti public
label: BODY

text: schools, these buildings are enclosed within a high, fortified stone and brick wall and have an unarmed guard at
label: BODY

text: the single entrance, to protect the children from intruders or other harm. Even children who are late to school are
label: BODY

text: stopped by the guard, and must receive approval from the principal before being allowed to enter. The standard
label: BODY

text: elementary school day schedule throughout Kuwait runs from 7:30 a.m. to 1:20 p.m., after which the children go
label: BODY

text: home to lunch (children may bring snacks to eat during breaks). The children have seven 40-minute class periods
label: BODY

text: over the course of the school day, broken by a 20-minute recess period after the second class, and by a 15-minute
label: BODY

text: prayer period break after the fourth class. However, not all academic subjects receive the same amount of time.
label: BODY

text: Two of the daily 40-minute periods are devoted to Arabic reading and writing, and two more 40-minute periods
label: BODY

text: each day are given to mathematics. Only one 40-minute period a day is spent on English. The remaining two
label: BODY

text: daily periods are divided among several subjects: science (which is studied for three periods a week), Islamic
label: BODY

text: religious studies (also studied for three periods each week), social science, physical education, music, and art.
label: BODY

text: All elementary public schools have between 10-15 teachers for different subjects and are trained to teach from
label: BODY

text: 1-5 grades. For example, in each school selected for this study, there were 10-13 English language teachers who
label: BODY

text: randomly teach students from grades 1-5 every year, based on the school timetable and how the subjects are
label: BODY

text: distributed throughout the day. That is, one English teacher teaches first, second, and fifth grade for a whole
label: BODY

text: school year, whereas another one teaches third and fourth grade, and so on. Furthermore, children stay in a single
label: BODY

text: www.ccsenet.org/ies
label: BODY

text: International Education Studies
label: BODY

text: classroom throughout the day (except for recess and prayers). All teachers use the curriculum prescribed in the
label: BODY

text: textbooks which are given to all teachers and students around the country by the MOE. Also, according to the
label: BODY

text: regulations of the MOE, all mainstream teachers have unexpected visits from the ministry supervisors and school
label: BODY

text: principals for evaluation. Because the MOE and the College of Basic Education (CBE), a college that trains and
label: BODY

text: graduates teachers mainly for primary levels, work closely together, the teacher trainees are assigned different
label: BODY

text: schools for their practicum course. Furthermore, the 20 trainees enrolled in the practicum course had already
label: BODY

text: completed a micro-teaching course, which is a core course the trainees have to pass before they graduate with a
label: BODY

text: degree in teaching English as a foreign language from the CBE. As soon as the practicum course starts with
label: BODY

text: every semester in every school year, the CBE contacts the MOE to inform the ministry about the number of
label: BODY

text: students who will be enrolled in the practicum course. In return, the MOE will assign the schools where the
label: BODY

text: practicum will be conducted. Then, the teacher trainees contact the assigned schools for their practicum. As soon
label: BODY

text: as the teacher trainees arrive to these assigned schools, each of them has 2 weeks to observe mainstream teachers
label: BODY

text: teach before she takes over one of the mainstream teachers' classrooms. The teacher trainee is just a
label: BODY

text: non-participating observer and sits at the back of the classroom and observes the class without interfering in it.
label: BODY

text: Before the beginning of the practicum course, I approached the school district authorities to get permission and
label: BODY

text: official letters for the principals to guarantee access to the schools for the research. Furthermore, because the
label: BODY

text: teacher trainees were observing the experienced teachers for their practicum, I approached the 10-13 experienced
label: BODY

text: teachers in each school one week before the practicum started. I explained the scope of the study and got
label: BODY

text: approval from at least 2-4 experienced teachers in each school. Then, I approached the principals of these 20
label: BODY

text: schools and asked them to assign these experienced teachers who had agreed to fill out the questionnaire first
label: BODY

text: and then the observation for the practicum course.
label: BODY

text: 2.2 The Instrument
label: BODY

text: A non-participant observation and a questionnaire were used for this study. The questionnaire was handed to the
label: BODY

text: experienced teachers to be filled out by them before their class began. The same teacher trainee then observed
label: BODY

text: the experienced classroom teachers and wrote her comments in her journal. Each trainee had a chance to observe
label: BODY

text: 4–6 teachers per week in the assigned school (an average of 1 teacher per day) and report her observations to the
label: BODY

text: author at the end of the day. The observation was carried out in the classrooms for the entire period of the class,
label: BODY

text: i.e., 40 minutes. Based on the teacher trainees' journal, the author analyzed what was written and cross checked
label: BODY

text: with other trainees. The researcher's questionnaire was guided by a checklist, developed by Christison and
label: BODY

text: Bassano (1996), and used by the author as a guide for experienced teachers and teacher trainees self evaluation.
label: BODY

text: 2.3 Data Analysis
label: BODY

text: 2.3.1 Questionnaire
label: BODY

text: To identify the differences between categories (learning environment, individuals, and activities) and the
label: BODY

text: corresponding sub-categories in the teachers’ self-assessed performance, the overall score achieved by each
label: BODY

text: teacher in each case was calculated by summing up the values of their responses. For example, a score of 9 in the
label: BODY

text: sub-category ‘Relationship to Students’ was achieved if a teacher believed she had an excellent performance in
label: BODY

text: all items within this subcategory (answers = 3 in all cases). Next, scores were transformed into a proportion of
label: BODY

text: the maximum possible score achieved; this enabled to compare categories with different numbers of questions.
label: BODY

text: For example, in the sub-category ‘Relationship to Students,’ the maximum possible score was 9. For a subject
label: BODY

text: with a total score of 7 (two answers ‘excellent/3’ and one answer ‘improvement is needed/1’), the calculated
label: BODY

text: proportion was 7/9 or approximately 0.77. The maximum possible score of individuals who did not respond to
label: BODY

text: all questions or indicated that a question was ‘not applicable’ was adjusted accordingly. The author also
label: BODY

text: conducted an exploratory analysis to examine potential associations between the scores in each category by
label: BODY

text: using Spearman rank correlations.
label: BODY

text: 2.3.2 Observation
label: BODY

text: The instrument on which the observation was based included the same items as the questionnaire. To ensure the
label: BODY

text: credibility of the teacher’s response to the questionnaire as well as to triangulate and assure the validity of the
label: BODY

text: conclusions, the author requested the teacher trainees to observe the teacher as many times as possible. The
label: BODY

text: reason for using the same items on the questionnaire for the teacher trainees to follow in their observation is to
label: BODY

text: allow for more rigorous comparison and contrast between the teacher’s response to the questionnaire and how
label: BODY

text: she teaches her lesson inside the classroom. Based on exploration of Kuwaiti EFL teachers’ classroom practices,
label: BODY

text: teacher trainees found that teaching is a very personal activity, and it is not surprising that individual teachers
label: BODY

text: brought to teaching very different beliefs and assumptions about what constitutes effective teaching. EFL
label: BODY

text: teachers had their classes organized and the instructional events are structured to a large extent on the nature of
label: BODY

text: www.ccsenet.org/ies
label: BODY

text: International Education Studies
label: BODY

text: the language that students hear and use in the classroom. The analysis classified two sets of characteristics that
label: BODY

text: appeared to distinguish classes that work for language learning from those that do not. The first set relates to the
label: BODY

text: way the classes are structured or are organized for instruction, the second to the way language is used in lessons
label: BODY

text: (Richards, 1997). Class structure as observed by the teacher trainees that EFL lessons worked effectively,
label: BODY

text: usually followed the following procedure:
label: BODY

text: A lesson began with a short statement of goals to be covered for the day and followed by a short review of
label: BODY

text: the previous day.
label: BODY

text: New materials were presented in small steps with student practice after each step.
label: BODY

text: Instructions and explanations were given in a clear and detailed manner.
label: BODY

text: A high level of active practice was provided for all students.
label: BODY

text: Questions were asked and then checked for student understanding and eliciting of the responses.
label: BODY

text: Students were guided during initial practice.
label: BODY

text: Systematic feedback and corrections were provided.
label: BODY

text: Explicit instruction and practice were provided for paired and group work exercises, and students were
label: BODY

text: monitored during these work sessions.
label: BODY

text: Furthermore, teachers mainly used tape or CD recorder, where data storage devices and computers were not
label: BODY

text: available to them. Authentic materials and learner-centered activities were not used as often. In some classes, the
label: BODY

text: teacher trainees reported that 58.7% of the teachers rated their performance from the questionnaire as excellent
label: BODY

text: and 27.5% as good when it comes to activities and materials; however, when the teacher trainees analyzed the
label: BODY

text: classroom observation, they realized that the teachers had no power to develop and implement new strategies for
label: BODY

text: English teaching. The teachers acknowledged that these problems were fostered by the officials at the education
label: BODY

text: ministry, who discouraged English teachers from exploring or using any materials other than the required
label: BODY

text: textbooks and activity books.
label: BODY

text: 3. Interpretation of Results
label: HH1

text: Responses were marked according to the following scale: (3) Excellent, (2) Good, (1) Needs improvement, (0)
label: BODY

text: Not applicable. All the data were transferred directly to SPSS for analysis. There are three main topics in the
label: BODY

text: questionnaire, namely learning environment, individuals and activity, under which are various sub-categories.
label: BODY

text: The first category to be reviewed is the learning environment. This category is divided into three sub-categories,
label: BODY

text: namely the relationship to students, classroom, and presentation. In the second sub-category classroom, 2
label: BODY

text: questions were asked: are class arranged according to the class activity? And are materials and equipment
label: BODY

text: needed for a class set up before the class begins? The third sub-category presentation consisted of seven
label: BODY

text: questions, each of which focused on the teachers’ presentation skill and performance. To obtain a general view
label: BODY

text: in the presentation field, the mean was obtained from all the answers provided by the participants in the seven
label: BODY

text: questions. The next category in the questionnaire is related to individuality. This category consists of five
label: BODY

text: subcategories, namely, physical health, self-concepts, aptitude and perception, reinforcement, and development.
label: BODY

text: Each subcategory contains three to five statements, each of which needs to be rated by the participants according
label: BODY

text: to their performance. The final topic in the questionnaire is “the activity” category. This category consists of two
label: BODY

text: sub-categories, namely “interaction” and “language.” The first one involves seven statements, which were
label: BODY

text: answered by the participants in light of their teaching context. However, the last five statements in the interaction
label: BODY

text: subcategory are related to what the students are saying (content) rather than error correcting. In addition,
label: BODY

text: teachers rated themselves high on how these activities are geared toward the outside world.
label: BODY

text: Figure 1 shows that in all three categories, learning environment (relationship to students, classroom,
label: BODY

text: presentation), individuals (physical health, self concepts, aptitude & perception, reinforcement, development),
label: BODY

text: and activity (interaction, language), most EFL teachers rated their teaching performance positively, as indicated
label: BODY

text: by the fact that most answers were within the 'Excellent' and 'Good' categories. Within learning environment,
label: BODY

text: performance was especially high for question Q7, namely, their assessment of their voice volume in class (see
label: BODY

text: Tables 1, 2, and 3 for the corresponding question codes and their description). The results also show that the area
label: BODY

text: where teachers believe there is more room for improvement is how students are divided into groups and based on
label: BODY

text: certain physical or may be cognitive features. However, teachers thought that their writing and speaking clearly
label: BODY

text: was not applicable due to the fact that taped materials were mainly used inside the classroom. In addition, within
label: BODY

text: the same category (learning environment), most teachers thought they had an excellent presentation skills,
label: BODY

text: whereas as the teacher trainee observed that the teachers were almost never communicative in the exercises
label: BODY

text: www.ccsenet.org/ies
label: BODY

text: International Education Studies
label: BODY

text: carried out in the classrooms. There was very little freedom and lack of predictability in what teacher or students
label: BODY

text: did or said. The teachers were in control of the activities, and the students tended to passively parrot the teacher’s
label: BODY

text: English words or phrases. The students did not ask questions, and the teachers’ recitation and discussion
label: BODY

text: questions were narrow and drill-oriented and did not encourage anything besides parroting. Not only the students,
label: BODY

text: but the teachers were also passive and restrictive in what they did. In the different classes around Kuwait, under
label: BODY

text: teachers with different personalities and ideas, the teacher trainees saw identical classes that resembled closed
label: BODY

text: copies of each other. The same drills were held to give children experience saying the same material, followed
label: BODY

text: by the same games or songs, using the same handouts, wall charts, flashcards, or tape recordings.
label: BODY

text: After the students practiced a new item for a few times, the teachers often assumed that the students had learned
label: BODY

text: it and accelerated the pace of teaching in order to move to the next item on the agenda. The overriding goal of
label: BODY

text: these teachers seemed to be the completion of the step-by-step, class-by-class plan supplied by the MOE,
label: BODY

text: regardless of whether they thought the students understood or were interested. Keeping pace with the other
label: BODY

text: teachers seemed to be the main priority of all the teachers.
label: BODY

text: Although the majority of teacher participants have shown confidence in their performance and have rated it as
label: BODY

text: excellent or good, for Questions 10 and 12, namely the target language ability, less than 2% felt that language
label: BODY

text: activities that lead to proficiency level as well as the information gained inside the classroom links the students
label: BODY

text: to the outside world spoke the truth based on the analysis of the data collected during the observation. Almost all
label: BODY

text: the students were not exposed to native-speaker pronunciation during the English class, and many of these
label: BODY

text: teachers modeled several grammatical errors. The class activities observed by the teacher trainees consisted of
label: BODY

text: vocabulary drills, exercises, and games, almost entirely without translation, and the meanings of words were
label: BODY

text: indicated contextually by pictures or gestures. The entire class would chorus the answers first, and later,
label: BODY

text: individual students would be called on. The teacher trainees noticed that some students seemed more proficient
label: BODY

text: and knowledgeable than others, and that classes often ended with some students still not seeming to understand
label: BODY

text: the vocabulary. Students’ mistakes were not corrected at once, but were ignored, to avoid their discouragement
label: BODY

text: or humiliation; later, the teacher or another student would model the correct answer.
label: BODY

text: Figure 2 confirms that self-assessment rating was highly positive and consistent across categories, as indicated
label: BODY

text: by the observation of the graph, that in all cases scores were close to the maximum possible score within each
label: BODY

text: category. However, most of the teachers considered themselves as good within all the subcategories.
label: BODY

text: The exploratory correlation analyses conducted (Figure 3) indicates a high degree of consistency in the answers
label: BODY

text: to the questionnaire by each teacher. As shown in the figure, with the exception of the association between the
label: BODY

text: scores of ‘Relationship to Students’ and ‘Language’ (not significant: NS in the graph), all correlations were
label: BODY

text: significant. The strongest association (darkest square in Figure 3) was between the scores of the categories
label: BODY

text: ‘Aptitude & Perception’ and ‘Reinforcement’. This result indicates that a strong positive correlation between the
label: BODY

text: two variables. However, if we look at the same figure 3, the scores for self-concepts and the interaction and the
label: BODY

text: development and language were very low compared to the other categories. However, based on the classrooms
label: BODY

text: observations, the teachers showed lack of accuracy in terms of implementing the technique, such as active
label: BODY

text: involvement in language use and student-centered activities. Throughout the period of teacher trainees’
label: BODY

text: observation, not only novice teachers but more experienced teachers also followed these lessons based on the
label: BODY

text: teacher’s manual provided by the MOE, mostly without any deviation, just like actors following a script. The
label: BODY

text: teachers seemed convinced that they were required to do this by the MOE. Students’ competence and
label: BODY

text: understanding often seemed to be irrelevant. Therefore, instruction tended to resemble “parrot learning,” in
label: BODY

text: which many students made sounds without knowing why.
label: BODY

text: The lessons in the manual are also fairly teacher-centered, and became even more so because the teachers did not
label: BODY

text: introduce pair work or small group work, although it is permitted by the manual. A teacher-centered approach is
label: BODY

text: clearly necessary to some degree with novice students. But the manual does not suggest, for instance, that
label: BODY

text: students might ask for the English names of objects they bring to class or for the English names for Arabic words,
label: BODY

text: a communicative activity that would have kept the students interested. Presumably this is because such activities
label: BODY

text: could have involved some translation (or perhaps because the teachers might not always have known the English
label: BODY

text: words).
label: BODY

text: Answers

text: Total

text: Relationship with students
label: HH1

text: 1. I establish good eye contact with my class. I do not talk over
label: BODY

text: their heads, to the blackboard, or to just one individual.
label: BODY

text: 2. If I tend to teach predominantly to one area of the classroom, I
label: BODY

text: am aware of this. I make a conscious effort at all times to pay
label: BODY

text: attention to all students equally.
label: BODY

text: 3. I divide my students into small groups in an organized and
label: BODY

text: principled manner. I recognize that these groups should differ in
label: BODY

text: size and composition, varying with the objective of the group
label: BODY

text: activity.
label: BODY

text: Classroom
label: HH1

text: 4. I arrange the seating in my class to suit the class activity for
label: BODY

text: the day.
label: BODY

text: 5. When I need special materials or equipment, I have them set
label: BODY

text: up before the class begins.
label: BODY

text: Presentation
label: HH1

text: 6. My handwriting on the blackboard and charts is legible from
label: BODY

text: all locations in the classroom. It is large enough to accommodate
label: BODY

text: students with vision impairments.
label: BODY

text: 7. I speak loudly enough to be heard in all parts of the classroom
label: BODY

text: and I enunciate clearly.
label: BODY

text: 8. I vary the exercises in class, alternating rapid and slow paced
label: BODY

text: activities to keep up maximum interest level in the class.
label: BODY

text: 9. I am prepared to give a variety of explanations, models or
label: BODY

text: descriptions, understanding that one explanation may not be
label: BODY

text: sufficient for all students.
label: BODY

text: 10. I help the students form working principles and
label: BODY

text: generalizations.
label: BODY

text: 11. I use new skills or concepts long enough so that they are
label: BODY

text: retained and thus future application is possible.
label: BODY

text: 12. I plan for “thinking time” for my students so that they can
label: BODY

text: organize their thoughts and plan what they are going to say or
label: BODY

text: do.
label: BODY

text: Physical Health
label: HH1

text: 1. I know which students have visual or aural impairments and make
label: BODY

text: them seat as close to my usual teaching position as possible.
label: BODY

text: 2. I am aware that a student’s attention span varies from day to day
label: BODY

text: depending on mental and physical health and external distractions. I
label: BODY

text: pace my class activities to accommodate the strengths. I don’t continue
label: BODY

text: with an activity which may exhaust or bore them.
label: BODY

text: 3. I begin my class with a simple activity to wake the students up and
label: BODY

text: get them working together.
label: BODY

text: 4. I am sensitive to individual students who have bad days. I don’t
label: BODY

text: press a student who is incapable of performing at the usual level.
label: BODY

text: 5. I try to challenge students who are at their best.
label: BODY

text: 6. If I am having a bad day and feel it might affect my normal teaching
label: BODY

text: style, I let my students know so there is no misunderstanding about my
label: BODY

text: feelings for them.
label: BODY

text: Self-Concept
label: HH1

text: 7. I treat my students with the same respect that I expect them to show
label: BODY

text: me.
label: BODY

text: 8. I plan “one-centered” activities which give all students an
label: BODY

text: opportunity at some point to feel important and accepted.
label: BODY

text: 9. I like to teach and have a good time teaching — on most days.
label: BODY

text: Aptitude Perception
label: HH1

text: 10. I am aware that my students learn differently. Some students are
label: BODY

text: visual-receptive, some are motor-receptive, and others are audio-
label: BODY

text: receptive
label: BODY

text: 11. My exercises are varied, some are visual, aural, oral and
label: BODY

text: kinesthetic. I provide models, examples, and experiences to maximize
label: BODY

text: learning in each of these areas
label: BODY

text: 12. I know basic concepts in the memory process. When applicable, I
label: BODY

text: make use of techniques such as backward buildup and association to
label: BODY

text: aid students in rapid skill acquisition.
label: BODY

text: Reinforcement
label: HH1

text: 13. I tell students when they have done well, but I don’t let praise
label: BODY

text: become mechanical.
label: BODY

text: 14. I finish my class period in a way which will review the new
label: BODY

text: concepts presented during the class period. My students can
label: BODY

text: immediately evaluate their understanding of those concepts.
label: BODY

text: 15. My tests are well-planned and produced.
label: BODY

text: 16. I make’ my system of grading clear to my students so that there are
label: BODY

text: no misunderstandings of expectations.
label: BODY

text: Development
label: HH1

text: 17. I keep myself updated on new techniques in the ESL profession by
label: BODY

text: attending conferences and workshops and by reading pertinent
label: BODY

text: professional articles and books.
label: BODY

text: 18. I realize that there is no one right way to present any lesson. I try
label: BODY

text: new ideas where and when they seem appropriate.
label: BODY

text: 19. I observe other EFL teachers so that I can get other ideas and
label: BODY

text: compare them to my own teaching style. I want to have several ideas
label: BODY

text: for teaching any one concept.

text: 1. I minimize my role in conducting the activities.

text: 4. Conclusion
label: HH1

text: One of our greatest challenges as we prepare teachers for the complexity of foreign language instruction is to
label: BODY

text: continue to believe that we are preparing teachers to make change. Through the micro-teaching and the
label: BODY

text: practicum courses, we stress the disparities between what we might want to see in classrooms and what they are
label: BODY

text: actually experiencing in schools. Teacher trainees often report with delight the opportunity to work alongside a
label: BODY

text: true mentor (classroom teacher), a teacher with a belief that second language instruction is challenging but
label: BODY

text: wonderful. In other words, teacher trainees should take the initiative to work with colleagues for their own
label: BODY

text: development; by this way, they can gain an inside perspective on other teachers’ experiences and raise their
label: BODY

text: awareness through reflecting on their own teaching.
label: BODY

text: Generally speaking, most teachers seem to be confident as the data has shown that all the answers were mainly
label: BODY

text: either excellent or good. Figure 1 summarizes the answers to the research question (1-3). It indicates that the
label: BODY

text: teachers have high level of performance in relation to the items on the questionnaire based on the three main
label: BODY

text: categories: learning environment, individuals, and activity. It is worth considering that a few teachers who
label: BODY

text: participated in this research and chose the “not applicable” answer were mostly those who not only felt it was
label: BODY

text: irrelevant to teach English but also did not properly teach English in their classes.
label: BODY

text: According to the note-taking during the observations, it is apparent that the teachers do not perform in the same
label: BODY

text: way as stated in the questionnaire. The teachers felt that they had insufficient opportunities in which they could
label: BODY

text: make mistakes without being judged; therefore, it was better for them to follow the syllabus and the teacher’s
label: BODY

text: manual. They also experienced difficulty finding opportunities to reflect upon their own performance and to
label: BODY

text: identify and address the real needs of learners.
label: BODY

text: Peer observation and reflection on own teaching are considered as important by teacher trainees because this
label: BODY

text: helps them in search of learning and adapting to new teaching environment through observing their fellow peers
label: BODY

text: and reflecting on their own teaching once they start this profession. In this study, all teachers rated themselves as
label: BODY

text: www.ccsenet.org/ies
label: BODY

text: International Education Studies
label: BODY

text: high as possible for the categories assessed on the questionnaire. They gave themselves higher score regardless
label: BODY

text: of the quality of their performance as was observed. Furthermore, teachers needed to feel secure in EFL teaching
label: BODY

text: environment. Consequently, they experienced anxiety and frustration. This frustration became apparent after the
label: BODY

text: administration of the questionnaire. Thus, there should be a technique for comprehensive and objective self
label: BODY

text: observation for teachers. However, because the questionnaire was used as against observation, the teacher did
label: BODY

text: not feel a sense of security in EFL teaching environment. The findings indicate that the participants (teachers)
label: BODY

text: conceptualized practice in concern with their beliefs about English learning, teaching, their teacher role, and
label: BODY

text: unique context factors, but in reality, they were merely following the guidelines of the MOE of Kuwait.
label: BODY

text: 4.1 Study Limitations
label: BODY

text: One limitation of this study was the presence of the teacher trainee as an observer for the experienced teacher,
label: BODY

text: which was awkward decision to follow. Second, the findings of this study cannot be generalized to the entire
label: BODY

text: population of English teachers, because this study dealt only with elementary school teachers. Finally, the study
label: BODY

text: focused on Kuwaiti elementary school English teachers working in public elementary schools. Information about
label: BODY

text: teachers in private schools and about foreign teachers were not included in this article.
label: BODY

text: 4.2 Future Direction for the Research
label: BODY

text: The Ministry of Education should relax its curriculum guidelines so that creative teachers feel free do their best
label: BODY

text: teaching. The official curriculum has not served as a framework of goals, within which the teachers may develop
label: BODY

text: their own teaching styles, but instead has been functioning as a straitjacket, imposing unimaginative,
label: BODY

text: curriculum-centered teaching. Instead of laying out lesson plans for the entire year, the teachers’ manual might
label: BODY

text: set learning goals, and then offer a rich array of teaching techniques and materials for teachers to choose among
label: BODY

text: in developing their own lesson plans.
label: BODY
